greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number whose inverse cototient set has n elements.
comment: Note that 1 is the only number that has infinitely many cototient-inverses, namely, all the primes.
link: Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
formula: a(n) = min { k | A063740(k) = n }. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 11 2018
mathematica: With[{s = Array[Count[Range[#^2], k_ /; k - EulerPhi@ k == #] &, 300, 2]}, ReplacePart[TakeWhile[First@ FirstPosition[s, #] + 1 & /@ Range[0, Max@ s], IntegerQ], 2 -> 0]] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jan 11 2018 *)
xref: Cf. A000010, A051953 (cototient: n - phi(n)), A063507.
Cf. A063740 (number of k such that cototient(k) = n).
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Aug 13 2001
